intro: Omphalocarpum bequaertii, commonly known as the African burr bush, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its woody shrub habit and produces distinctive, spiny fruits that encase its seeds. The plant belongs to the family Leguminosae, also known as the Fabaceae family, which includes many nitrogen-fixing species. Its leaves are typically compound, consisting of several small leaflets, and it thrives in dry, sandy soils. The plant is often used in traditional medicine and for its hardy, drought-resistant properties.
